dcterms_identifier: This large tree grows in the center of the lawn in front of Rand/Sarratt and is almost equidistant from Rand,
Black oak is another member of the red oak group and its
leaves have variable hairiness, from tufts of blond hair where the veins
come together to entirely covered with hair (the species name, velutina,
comes from the term for velvety hair).  The sinuses of the

The best way to recognize this species is by observing its

Black oak can be found in a variety of habitats, but tends to be on drier
sites than northern red oak.  This particular tree has no branches near the
ground and unfortunately it is the only black oak on campus.  You may find
twigs and leaves on the ground to examine.  It is noteworthy in that it is described on
